Based on the documents on file, steering gear tests are required prior to departure, before entering restricted waters, and at regular intervals for specific components. Testing should also be conducted at any time if required or if the performance is doubted [4, Chapter 7.2 NAVIGATION > Steering Control Units and Power Units‚Äô Tests].

1. Steering Gear Test Prior Departure (Form N 019)

The N 019 - Steering Gear Test Prior Departure (Laminated) checklist must be completed within 12 hours prior to departure from a port [5, N 019 - Steering Gear Test Prior Departure (Laminated) > CHECK FOLLOWING WITHIN 12 HOURS PRIOR DEPARTURE FROM A PORT].

The required checks are divided among the Navigation Officer, Chief Engineer, and ETO:

Responsible Officer Required Checks
A. NAVIGATION OFFICER Bridge remote steering control systems
Steering positions on the bridge
Steering gear power units change-over
Steering gear power unit failure alarms (alarm panel)
Helm and rudder angle indicators
Rudder angle indicators in relation to actual rudder position
Communication system between bridge and steering gear compartment (electrical and em‚Äôcy powered telephones)
Full movement of the rudder according to steering gear capabilities (with main and emergency system use)
Check the timing of rudder movement from hard-over to hard-over, using each steering gear power unit singly and together (Time hard-over to hard-over with one power unit sec and two power units sec)
Compass in steering gear room
Simple operating instructions with a block diagram showing change-over procedures for remote st. gear control systems displayed on bridge and in the steering gear compartment
B. CHIEF ENGINEER Main steering gear unit
Auxiliary steering gear unit or rudder arrester gear
Remote steering gear control system
Emergency power supply
Visual inspection of st. gear and its connecting linkages
Visual verification of hydraulic oil level in system
Rudder carrier bearing and bottom sea gland
Smooth pumps operation
Absence of abnormal noise and heat
C. ETO Steering gear power unit failure alarms
Automatic isolating arrangements, other automatic equipment
Remote steering gear control systems power failure alarms
Hydraulic oil service tank low and low-low alarms

2. Testing Before Entering Restricted Waters

Before entering restricted or coastal waters, the Officer of the Watch (OOW) must ensure full control of the steering functions by performing the following steps:

  1. Test the steering gear hard-over-to-hard-over from all manual steering positions on the bridge.
  2. Start both steering gear power units.

[6, Chapter 7.2 NAVIGATION > Navigation under Different Conditions]

3. Rudder Angle Indicator Test

The OOW must test the rudder angle indicators at regular intervals by taking the following steps:

  1. Set the rudder amidships and check that the indicator displays 0¬∞ (adjust the zero lever until it is centered at 0¬∞ when necessary).
  2. Set the rudder at an angle port and starboard and check that the indicator follows the order.
  3. Check that the device's indications are apparent and the dimmers are working properly.

[8, Chapter 7.2 NAVIGATION > Rudder Angle Indicator]

4. Steering with Transmitting Magnetic Compass (TMC) Check (Weekly)

The Master/OOW must test the steering with the Transmitting Magnetic Compass (TMC) weekly. The steps are:

  1. Verify no navigational hazards or other ships are in the ship‚Äôs close vicinity.
  2. Select the TMC input on Auto Pilot mode.
  3. Check that the course changes until it stabilizes on the course indicated by the TMC.
  4. Alter the Auto Pilot course to steer setting to each side by 10¬∞ and observe the Auto Pilot response.
  5. Bring the heading back to the original course and switch back to gyro input.
  6. Record the weekly test of TMC steering in the Bridge Log Book.

[9, Chapter 7.2 NAVIGATION > Auto Pilot Failure]
